pieces.title: Your Pieces (25 total)
pieces.description: Each side has 25 pieces with different movement patterns. The shape tells you how it moves:
pieces.intro: Each piece has a number value and moves differently:
pieces.pyramidMove: One step any way (like a king)
pieces.pyramidIntro: Pyramids are special. They have 4 different values you can choose from when you capture. This makes them super flexible!
pieces.pyramidRule1: Pick which value to use before you capture
pieces.pyramidRule2: That value becomes your piece's number for the math
pieces.pyramidRule3: You can pick different values each time - nothing is locked in
pieces.pyramidRule4: This makes Pyramids great for surprise attacks and helping other pieces
pieces.pyramidExample: White's Pyramid can capture Black's 16 using face 64 (multiple: 64√∑16=4), face 36 (multiple: 36√∑9=4, with Black's 9), or face 25 with equality if capturing Black's 25.
pieces.pyramidVisualTitle: Visual Example: Pyramid's Multiple Capture Options
pieces.pyramidVisualDesc: White's Pyramid (faces: 64, 49, 36, 25) is positioned to capture Black pieces. Notice the flexibility:
pieces.pyramidOption1: Move to I5: Choose face 64 ‚Üí captures 16 by multiple (64√∑16=4)
pieces.pyramidOption2: Move to H6: Choose face 49 ‚Üí captures 49 by equality (49=49)
pieces.pyramidOption3: Move to G5: Choose face 25 ‚Üí captures 25 by equality (25=25)

pyramid.name: Pyramid
pyramid.movement: One step any way (like a king)

capture.title: How to Capture
capture.description: You can only capture an enemy piece if your piece value has a mathematical relation to theirs:
capture.intro: You can capture an enemy piece only if your piece's value relates mathematically to theirs:
capture.equalityCaption: White Circle (25) can capture Black Circle (25) by equality
capture.multipleCaption: White Square (64) can capture Black Triangle (16) because 64 √∑ 16 = 4
capture.sumCaption: White Circle (9) can capture Black Circle (25) using helper Triangle (16): 9 + 16 = 25
capture.differenceCaption: White Triangle (30) can capture Black Triangle (20) using helper Circle (10): 30 - 10 = 20
capture.productCaption: White Circle (5) can capture Black Circle (25) using helper Circle (5): 5 √ó 5 = 25
capture.ratioCaption: White Triangle (20) can capture Black Circle (5) using helper Circle (4): 20 √∑ 4 = 5
capture.helpersDescription: Helpers are your other pieces on the board. They don't move - they just add their number to the math. The game shows you which captures work when you click a piece.
capture.helpersDesc: Helpers are your other pieces still on the board ‚Äî they don't move, just provide their value for the math. The game will show you valid captures when you select a piece.
capture.example1Desc: White's 64 (square) can capture Black's 16 (triangle) because 64 is a multiple of 16
capture.pyramidIntro: Pyramids have 4 face values, making them incredibly versatile. You choose which face to use when attempting a capture, allowing one Pyramid to threaten multiple enemy pieces.
capture.pyramidEx1Desc: White's Pyramid (faces: 64, 49, 36, 25) can capture Black's 49 by choosing face 49 for equality (49 = 49)
capture.pyramidEx1Note: Face selection: White declares face 49 ‚Üí 49 = 49 (equality) ‚Üí Capture succeeds! The Pyramid could also capture pieces valued 64, 36, or 25 using the corresponding faces.
capture.pyramidEx2Desc: White's Pyramid uses face 25 + helper 20 = Black's 45 (25 + 20 = 45)
capture.pyramidEx2Note: Face selection: White chooses face 25 and declares helper at D4 (value 20) ‚Üí 25 + 20 = 45 (sum) ‚Üí Capture succeeds! By selecting different faces, the same Pyramid could capture other values using various helpers.
capture.pyramidEx3Desc: Black's Pyramid (faces: 36, 25, 16, 4) can capture White's 9 using face 36 (multiple: 36 √∑ 9 = 4)
capture.pyramidEx3Note: Face selection: Black chooses face 36 ‚Üí 36 √∑ 9 = 4 (multiple) ‚Üí Capture succeeds! Note: Black could also use face 4 with a helper 5 for sum (4 + 5 = 9), showing multiple valid approaches.

harmony.title: Harmonies: The Coolest Way to Win
harmony.intro: A Harmony is how you win the game. Get 3 of your pieces into enemy territory in a straight line. Their values must form a mathematical pattern.
harmony.introDetail: Think of it like a number sequence. There are 3 types of patterns you can make:
harmony.arithmeticDesc: The middle number is exactly between the other two. Equal spacing.
harmony.arithmeticTip: Small circles (2-9) work great here. Look for equal gaps! Example: 6, 9, 12
harmony.arithmeticCaption: White pieces 6, 9, 12 in a row in enemy territory form an arithmetic progression
harmony.geometricDesc: Multiply by the same number each time. Equal ratios.
harmony.geometricTip: Square numbers work great! Example: 4, 8, 16 (multiply by 2 each time)
harmony.geometricCaption: White pieces 4, 8, 16 in a row in enemy territory form a geometric progression
harmony.harmonicDesc: Based on musical harmonies. Hardest to spot.
harmony.harmonicTip: These are rare. Just memorize these combos: 3-4-6, 4-6-12, 6-8-12, 6-10-15
harmony.harmonicCaption: White pieces 6, 8, 12 in a row in enemy territory form a harmonic progression
harmony.enemyTerritory: All 3 pieces must be on opponent's side (White: rows 5-8, Black: rows 1-4)
harmony.straightLine: Row, column, or diagonal. No scattered pieces!
harmony.adjacent: The 3 pieces must be next to each other with no gaps
harmony.survival: After you declare harmony, opponent gets ONE turn to break it
harmony.victoryRule: If it survives, you win on your next turn!
harmony.startWith2: Get 2 pieces deep first. Figure out which 3rd piece completes the pattern. Then push that piece forward. They might not see it coming!
harmony.useCommon: Numbers like 6, 8, 9, 12, 16 work in lots of patterns. If you get these deep, check what 3rd piece finishes the job.
harmony.protect: While building, keep other pieces nearby to defend. One capture ruins everything!
harmony.block: If opponent has 2 pieces deep, figure out what 3rd piece they need. Block that spot or capture one of their pieces ASAP.
harmony.calculate: Before declaring, make sure opponent can't capture any of your 3 pieces. If they can, protect first or wait.

victory.title: How to Win
victory.harmonyDesc: Form a mathematical progression with 3 pieces in enemy territory. If it survives your opponent's next turn, you win!
victory.exampleCaption: White pieces 4, 8, 16 form a geometric progression in enemy territory. Black cannot break it - White wins!
victory.harmonyNote: This is the primary victory condition in Rithmomachia
victory.exhaustionDesc: If your opponent has no legal moves at the start of their turn, they lose.
victory.tip1: Control the center - easier to push forward
victory.tip2: Small pieces are fast - circles can slip into enemy side quickly
victory.tip3: Big pieces are powerful - harder to capture
victory.tip4: Watch for their harmonies - don't let 3 pieces get deep
victory.tip5: Pyramids are flexible - pick the right value for each capture

strategy.title: Strategy & Tactics
strategy.intro: Rithmomachia rewards both mathematical insight and strategic planning. Success requires balancing territorial control, piece preservation, and mathematical opportunities.

controlCenter.title: Control the Center
controlCenter.desc: Advance pieces toward the 8-column empty center (columns E‚ÄìL). This provides mobility and creates capturing opportunities from multiple angles.

developCircles.title: Develop Small Circles First
developCircles.desc: Your small circles (2‚Äì9) in columns D and M are mobile and versatile. Move them toward the center early to establish presence and create helper networks.

protectPyramid.title: Protect Your Pyramid
protectPyramid.desc: The Pyramid is your most flexible piece (4 face values) but moves only 1 square. Keep it behind advancing lines until mid-game when mathematical threats are clear.

knowNumbers.title: Know Your Numbers
knowNumbers.desc: Memorize key mathematical relationships in your army. Identify which pieces form factors, multiples, and sums‚Äîthis speeds up tactical calculation.

helperNetworks.title: Build Helper Networks
helperNetworks.desc: Position pieces so multiple helpers can support captures. For example, if you have pieces valued 5 and 10, you can capture 15 (sum), 5 (difference), or 50 (product) when your mover is positioned correctly.

createThreats.title: Create Capture Threats
createThreats.desc: Force your opponent to defend multiple pieces simultaneously. Even if you can't execute all captures, the threat constrains their options and controls the tempo.

thinkDefensively.title: Think Defensively
thinkDefensively.desc: After each move, check which of your pieces can be captured. High-value pieces like squares (169, 225, 289, 361) are vulnerable to many relations‚Äîposition them behind defenders or in protected squares.

exchangeWhenAhead.title: Exchange When Ahead
exchangeWhenAhead.desc: If you've captured more pieces or higher values, simplify the position by trading pieces. This reduces your opponent's attacking options and brings you closer to exhaustion victory.

exhaustion.title: Exhaustion Victory (Attrition)
exhaustion.desc: Capture pieces systematically until your opponent has no legal moves. Focus on: eliminating mobile pieces (Squares and Triangles), blocking diagonals and ranks, and forcing the Pyramid into a corner.

points.title: Point Victory (Optional Rule)
points.desc: If enabled, capture 30 points worth of pieces (C=1, T=2, S=3, P=5). Hunt high-value targets and preserve your own heavy pieces. Trade advantageously.

commonMistakes.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistakes to Avoid
commonMistakes.movingWithoutCalc: Moving without calculation: Always check if your destination square is capturable by enemy pieces
commonMistakes.ignoringGeometry: Ignoring helper geometry: Helpers can be anywhere, but you still need a legal move path to capture
commonMistakes.neglectingHarmony: Neglecting harmony threats: If your opponent has 2 pieces in your territory forming part of a progression, block their third
commonMistakes.exposingPyramid: Leaving the Pyramid exposed: It moves only 1 square and has limited escape options‚Äîprotect it early

sacrifices.title: Positional Sacrifices
sacrifices.desc: Sometimes sacrificing a piece opens lines for your other pieces or forces your opponent into a worse position. Calculate the resulting imbalance before sacrificing.

pyramidFaces.title: Pyramid Face Selection
pyramidFaces.desc: Your Pyramid has 4 face values. In captures, choose the face that maximizes future flexibility. In harmony declarations, choose the face that completes the most valuable progression type.

tempo.title: Tempo and Initiative
tempo.desc: Each move that forces a defensive response gains tempo. String together forcing moves (captures, threats) to dictate the pace and prevent your opponent from executing their plan.
